trustfund: TF020290-IRISH CONSULTANTS TRUST FUND,TF033365-PAKISTAN - SECOND FAMILY HEALTH,TF033364-PAKISTAN - SECOND FAMILY HEALTH,TF032802-PAKISTAN - HEALTH,TF031939-PAKISTAN - SECOND FAMILY HEALTH PROJECT,TF031938-PAKISTAN - SECOND FAMILY HEALTH PROJECT

abstracts.cdata!:
The First Family Health Project's
            overall outcome is rated as satisfactory. The project inputs
            contributed to: improving access to and quality of maternal
            health services including family planning; enhancing staff
            development through in-service training, expansion of
            pre-service training capacity, and career enhancement
            programs of female paramedics; improving managerial
            capabilities; and strengthening the health management
            information system. The experience of the Area Focus
            Approach (AFA) confirmed the critical importance of
            availability of female paramedics and supportive supervision
            to improving performance of first level care facilities. The
            policy of training and eventual recruitment of local girls
            adopted by the Sindh government is a sustainable solution to
            the problem of regional shortages of female staff. It not
            only addresses multiple constraints including housing and
            security concerns to the retention of female personnel but
            also provides an element of accountability to the community.
            The AFA pilot has also underlined the need of training
            traditional birth attendants and linking them to the primary
            health system. Considerable potential exists for increasing
            collaboration between the Health Education and Nutrition
            units, existing nongovernmental organizations, and
            community-based organizations.
